div.head: Resources for Spoken Varieties
div.p: The number of digitally encoded Arabic language corpora has been on the rise in recent years. The following list is an attempt at listing those that are relevant to linguistic research and is by no means meant to be exhaustive. Please let us know about missing items.

div.head: CorpAfroAs
div.p: CorpAfroAs was an integrated pilot project that also produced Arabic data. On the project web site, you can find extensive information on how to build corpora of spoken language. The data is available.

div.head: CORVAM Speech corpus of Maghrebi varieties
div.p: This very recent development is a tool for the study of Arabic and Berber varieties in the Maghreb in terms of teaching and research and for the preservation of language and culture in the Maghreb. The corpus is a result of the research team nhəḍṛu. Dialectología y sociolingüística del Magreb, and has been conducted at the University of Zaragoza with the participation of members from other universities and research institutes both from Spain and abroad. The project has been been developed under the lead of Ángeles Vicente and the website is being hosted by the University of Zaragoza.

div.head: TUNICO
div.p: The TUNICO Corpus was created as part of the project Linguistic dynamics in the Greater Tunis Area: a corpus-based approach which ran from August 2013 until July 2016. TUNICO grew as a satellite project out of the VICAV project.

div.head: Tunisian Arabic Corpus
div.p: This is a comparatively large corpus of Tunisian Arabic mainly collected from the Internet. The corpus has a very nice web interface.

div.head: Corpus of Moroccan Arabic Writers of Short Stories and Literary Reviews
div.p: Information on this corpus can be found here.

div.head: In their own voices, in their own words: A sociolinguistically-informed corpus of Nigerian Arabic
div.p: This corpus which is hosted by the university of Bayreuth has been created by Jonathan Owens who has also published extensively about Nigerian Arabic.

div.head: Curras: Corpus for Palestinian Arabic
div.p: This corpus of 60k words consists in texts collected from Facebook, Twitter, "Watan Aa Water" scripts, and others. Every word in the corpus was manually annotated with a set of metadata attributes to describe the orthographical, morphological, and semantic features of the word such as part of speech, prefixes, stem, suffixes, dialect lemma, MSA lemma, surface, gender, number, mode, and a gloss in English.

div.head: Gumar Corpus
div.p: The Gulf Arabic Corpus (Gumar) was created as part of the Computational Approaches to Modeling Languages CAMeL lab in New York University Abu Dhabi NYUAD. The corpus contains a unique genre of written material, anonymous publicly published long conversational novels. A a huge collection of these novels was found online in one place. 1,200 MS Word documents were automatically downloaded.

div.head: Database of Arabic Dialects
div.p: The Database of Arabic Dialects was created through interviews conducted with informants from Algeria, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Morocco, Oman, Palestine, Saudi Arabia, Sudan and Syria. On the basis of a quite exhaustive questionnaire, the website allows to explore linguistic phenomena and to compare a wide range of dialects. The project was set up and organised by Yaron Matras at the University of Manchester.

div.head: Arabic Dialects Dataset
div.p: This collection is one of several corpora being provided by Mahmoud El-Haj (Lancaster University). It consists in transcriptions of Arabic script of Gulf, Egypt, Levantine and Tunisian Arabic dialects in addition to MSA.

div.head: Arabic Speech Corpus
div.p: The Arabic Speech Corpus was developed by Nawar Halabi at the University of Southampton. It was recorded in south Levantine Arabic (Damascian accent) using a professional studio. Synthesized speech as an output using this corpus has produced a high quality, natural voice. It is released here under a non-commercial creative commons license.
